Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation2: An emergency diversion cuts across three sectors at once, requiring rapid multi-sector coordination.
Story:
I stood in the kitchen, phone pressed to my ear, listening to my husband list the last-minute chores before his family arrived. The living room needed dusting, the guest towels were still in the dryer, and the food had to be set out just right. He sounded stressed, and I knew he expected me to help pull everything together, to be present and supportive, to make our home shine for his relatives. But as I reached for the vacuum, my work phone buzzed urgently. 

“Sector three, we have an emergency diversion—possible engine failure, crossing into your airspace,” the supervisor’s voice crackled. My heart pounded. I was needed at the radar, to coordinate with two other controllers, to keep the skies safe and prevent chaos. I could hear my husband in the background, calling for help with the table settings. My headset beeped again—another update from the tower. 

I felt split in two, the weight of both worlds pressing down. My family needed me here, but so did the pilots and passengers above. I stood frozen, torn between the demands of home and the urgency of the skies, not knowing which call to answer first.
